newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: NAMFISH AND NAMSEA PLAN TO MERGE.
newsitem.headline: NAMFISH AND NAMSEA PLAN TO MERGE.

text.p: Namibian groups Namibian Fishing Industries Ltd (Namfish) and Namibian Sea Products Ltd (Namsea) are to merge in a bid to up their capital base, the firms said Tuesday in statements with their half year results.

On September 30 the firms issued a cautionary statement saying they were in talks likely to effect their share prices. Now, in announcements in South African newspapers, a planned merger has been revealed.

"The directors have taken the decision to merge Namfish and Namsea with a view to creating a single entity with a stronger capital base. Advice is being sought on how best to achieve this," the firms said.
They added shareholders would be kept informed of future developments.
The news came at the same time as both firms, who already have an element of cross-shareholding, posted slips into the red.
Namfish saw attributable income slip to a $N13.63 million loss from a $N0.86 million profit, while Namsea saw a $N5.05 million profit turn into a $N5.31 million loss.
The main factor has been the total absence of any pilchard catches during the allotted fishing period.
"By the time the season closed on August 31 not a single can of pilchards had been produced in Walvis Bay from pilchards caught in Namibian waters," Namsea said.
The group added many scientists were baffled by the absence of fish.
"Research scientists have not been able to identify with any certainty the reasons for the non-availability of pilchards in Namibian waters nor for the shortage of fish generally," the firm said.
